creator: alice0775@yahoo.co.jp
summary: No job link(such as B, Bs, N ... etc) are displayed on ESR52

assigned_to_detail.name: nobody@mozilla.org
assigned_to_detail.real_name: Nobody; OK to take it and work on it

comments.text:
Today, No job links(such as B, Bs, N ... etc) are displayed on ESR52.

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Open https://treeherder.mozilla.org/#/jobs?repo=mozilla-inbound


Actual Results:
No job link(such as B, Bs, N ... etc) are displayed

Expected Results:
Job link(such as B, Bs, N ... etc) should be displayed.
And clicking on a job should be open detail pane.
comments.author: alice0775@yahoo.co.jp

comments.text:
Trying on ESR52, the web console shows:
`TypeError: NetworkError when attempting to fetch resource.`

I'm presuming this started as of the prod deploy earlier today, and was working fine before then? If so, the range is:
https://github.com/mozilla/treeherder/compare/c80e34213340...d4e811c76410

In that range is the commit where we start using the fetch API in more places (previously it was only used for login, the hidden auto-classify tab, intermittents-view, test-view):
https://github.com/mozilla/treeherder/pull/3568

The fetch API is supported by ESR52:
https://caniuse.com/#search=fetch

...however there is presumably some bug with it that's fixed in newer versions of Firefox.

To be honest this is likely wontfix from our side.
comments.author: emorley@mozilla.com

comments.text:
#1 Job link(such as B, Bs, N ... etc) are displayed.
https://hg.mozilla.org/integration/mozilla-inbound/pushloghtml?fromchange=f24dc887296771ed1d36f96caaed0e326c6f3d25&tochange=ee9c3cd7d55f2a00d416dee71ca3938926850739

#2 Clicking on a job should be open detail pane.
https://hg.mozilla.org/integration/mozilla-inbound/pushloghtml?fromchange=d133ea537108e8b7f9c23d951cfd288c964cf6c6&tochange=92692c9a4f1e7f9b1bb8968267298615de1bf695

It depends on at least bug 1331580 and bug 1378342 that are not implemented in ESR 52.
comments.author: alice0775@yahoo.co.jp

comments.text:
Ah great sleuthing! :-)

Looking at MDN, the support for URLSearchParams record is Firefox 54+:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URLSearchParams#Browser_compatibility

And for AbortController, Firefox 57+:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController#Browser_compatibility

Given both are supported by ESR60, I don't think it's worth spending too much time trying to replace these with alternate implementations (or have the bloat of a polyfill).
comments.author: emorley@mozilla.com

comments.text:
Since comment 3, bug 1450039 has been temporarily reverted in production due to causing bug 1465355.

As such, for now Treeherder production should now work in ESR52 (to the extent that it did before today, since bug 1464960 was pre-existing) until that bug relands.
comments.author: emorley@mozilla.com

comments.text: yep, now, it is working again.
comments.author: alice0775@yahoo.co.jp

comments.text: Treeherder does not work again on esr52 since around 11:00JST.
comments.author: alice0775@yahoo.co.jp

comments.text:
Hi! Yeah bug 1450039 was relanded after bug 1465355 and bug 1466149 were fixed, so Treeherder not working on ESR52 again is expected.

Since Treeherder is a developer facing tool, and developers ideally shouldn't be using ESR at all (let alone the prior ESR), this isn't something we plan on fixing - given that Treeherder works with ESR60/release/beta/nightly. 

If the use of ESR52 is due to your distro having outdated packages, I'd strongly recommend switching to the official Firefox packages instead rather than using the distro's package manager.

Thank you for reporting the bug and tracking down the regression ranges though :-)
comments.author: emorley@mozilla.com

comments.text:
(In reply to Ed Morley [:emorley] from comment #7)
> If the use of ESR52 is due to your distro having outdated packages, I'd
> strongly recommend switching to the official Firefox packages instead rather
> than using the distro's package manager.

Is there are authoritative set of instructions for how to install an official Firefox package onto a Linux system such that:

* It's installed into the PATH, without having to add ad-hoc directories to the PATH
* It takes precedence over / is not stomped on by distro package updates
* It's recognized as the system's default browser by other applications (e.g. clicking on a link in a terminal)

and so on?
comments.author: botond@mozilla.com

comments.text:
I have no idea, I only use Linux in VMs and not as my primary OS.

These sounds like great bugs to file against both Firefox Linux documentation and system default configuration.
comments.author: emorley@mozilla.com

comments.text: *** Bug 1467524 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
comments.author: emorley@mozilla.com
